sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Pitressin(R) Tannate in oil was discontinued in January of 1990 due to problems in obtaining raw materials.
  • Abdominal distension; Prophylaxis - Postoperative complication: initial, 5 units IM or SUBQ postoperatively; increase to 10 units at subsequent injections repeated at 3- or 4-hour intervals as needed
  • Cardiac arrest: 40 units IV/INTRAOSSEOUS to replace first or second dose of epinephrine given every 3 to 5 minutes (guideline dosing); 20 international units IV/CPR cycle in combination with epinephrine 1 mg IV/CPR cycle for the first 5 CPR cycles, plus methylprednisolone 40 mg IV during the first CPR cycle, has been used in clinical studies
  • Diabetes insipidus: 5 to 10 units SUBQ or IM repeated 2 or 3 times daily as needed
  • Diabetes insipidus: when given INTRANASALLY by spray or on pledgets, dose and interval must be determined for each patient
  • Diagnostic radiography of abdomen: 2 SUBQ or IM injections of 10 units each, given at 2 hours and at 30 minutes before films are exposed; an enema may be given before the roentgenogram
  • Septic shock; Adjunct: 0.01 to 0.04 unit/min IV infusion; in combination with 1 to 2 additional catecholamines
  • Shock, Vasodilatory: (postcardiotomy shock) initial dose, 0.03 units/min continuous IV, and titrate by 0.005 units/min at 10- to 15-minute intervals to MAX of 0.1 unit/min
  • Shock, Vasodilatory: (septic shock) initial dose, 0.01 unit/min continuous IV, and titrate by 0.005 units/min at 10- to 15-minute intervals to MAX of 0.07 units/min
  • Shock, Vasodilatory: maintenance, titrate to lowest dose to maintain target blood pressure
  • Shock, Vasodilatory: discontinuation, taper by 0.005 units/min every hour as needed to maintain target blood pressure, after target blood pressure has been sustained for 8 hours without catecholamine use
  • Water deprivation test: 5 units subQ

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Pitressin(R) Tannate in oil was discontinued in January of 1990 due to problems in obtaining raw materials.
  • safety and efficacy in pediatric patients with vasodilatory shock not established
  • Abdominal distension; Prophylaxis - Postoperative complication: for pediatric patients, reduce adult dose proportionately; adult dose: initial, 5 units IM or SUBQ postoperatively; increase to 10 units at subsequent injections repeated at 3- or 4-hour intervals as needed
  • Diabetes insipidus: for pediatric patients, reduce adult dose proportionately; adult dose: 5 to 10 units SUBQ or IM repeated 2 or 3 times daily as needed; when given INTRANASALLY by spray or on pledgets, dose and interval must be determined for each patient
  • Diagnostic radiography of abdomen: for pediatric patients, reduce adult dose proportionately; adult dose: 2 SUBQ or IM injections of 10 units each, given at 2 hours and at 30 minutes before films are exposed; an enema may be given before the roentgenogram

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• elderly: begin therapy at the lower end of the range and dose cautiously
  • cirrhosis: some patients with cirrhosis will respond to IV vasopressin doses as low as 0.13 units/min in the treatment of variceal hemorrhage

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Pitressin(R) Tannate in oil was discontinued in January of 1990 due to problems in obtaining raw materials [2].
  • Shock, Vasodilatory
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Pitressin(R) Tannate in oil was discontinued in January of 1990 due to problems in obtaining raw materials [2].
  • Abdominal distension; Prophylaxis - Postoperative complication
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Diagnostic radiography of abdomen
  • Septic shock; Adjunct
  • Water deprivation test

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: allergy or hypersensitivity to 8-L-arginine vasopressin or chlorobutanol

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- cardiac output may worsen if used in patients with impaired cardiac response

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Bradyarrhythmia, Tachyarrhythmia
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyponatremia
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Atrial fibrillation, Cardiac arrest, Decreased cardiac function, Hemorrhagic shock, Myocardial ischemia, Right heart failure
  • Dermatologic:Gangrenous disorder, Cutaneous
  • Gastrointestinal:Mesenteric vascular insufficiency
  • Hematologic:Hemorrhage
  • Hepatic:Increased bilirubin level
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Musculoskeletal:Limb ischemia
  • Renal:Renal impairment, acute
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary edema
  • Other:Water intoxication syndrome

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: This drug is a synthetic arginine vasopressin. The hormone vasopressin contracts vascular smooth muscle via V1 receptors coupled to phospholipase C, which stimulate the release of vasoconstrictive calcium. Splanchnic, renal, and cutaneous circulation are also affected at therapeutic doses. Gastrointestinal smooth muscle is contracted at pressor doses. At lower concentrations, vasopressin also stimulates V2 receptors, leading to an antidiuretic effect.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Renal: 6%, as unchanged drug
  • Total body clearance: 9 to 25 mL/min/kg

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
vasodilatory shock: dilute in NS or D5W to a final concentration of 1 unit/mL (100 units/100 mL) for fluid-restricted patients or 0.1 unit/mL (50 units/500 mL) for non-fluid-restricted patients.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: increased blood pressure in patients with vasodilatory shock who are hypotensive despite standard therapy may indicate efficacy

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    Injection Solution: 20 U/ML
  • Novaplus Vasopressin
    Injection Solution: 20 U/ML
  • Pitressin
    Injection Solution: 20 U/ML
  • Vasostrict
    Intravenous Solution: 20 U/ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient to report symptoms of angina, arrhythmias, or myocardial infarction.
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of water intoxication, such as drowsiness, listlessness, and headaches.
  • Side effects may include abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, vertigo, tremor, sweating, urticaria, ischemia (mesenteric, skin, digital), or hyponatremia.
  • Counsel patient to take with 1 to 2 glasses of water to reduce gastric symptoms when used for diabetes insipidus, abdominal distention, or diagnostic radiography.
